repository.corpname: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

langmaterial.language: Materials are mostly in English. Some correspondence and notes are in French.

did.abstract: Stephen E. Malawista, M.D, was a member of the Department of Internal Medicine and Chair of the Section of Rheumatology at Yale. His research focused on the mechanisms of inflammation relevant to rheumatology. He was best known as the co-discoverer of Lyme disease. His papers include correspondence, section annual reports, correspondence and drafts on papers submitted for publication, grants and contracts, popular material on Lyme disease, presentations, published papers, and research notes.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Stephen Evan Malawista, professor of medicine at Yale, was born in New York City and graduated from Harvard College (1954) and the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University (1958). He completed his residency training at Yale. After a brief stint in the Public Health Service, he was invited back to Yale in 1966, where he became chief of Rheumatology in the Department of Internal Medicine in 1967. As chief for 21 years, he built up the section to a major center for rheumatology. Malawista was known for his creativity in the laboratory, his observational skills as a clinician, and his wit as a colleague. His research focused on inflammation, especially neutrophils, and he made many important contributions. He developed the first screen for the prenatal diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease. But Malawista will be especially remembered as the co-discoverer in 1975 with Allen C. Steele, of Lyme disease. In addition to his previous areas of research, Malawista continued to investigate Lyme disease through the remainder of his career. He and his colleagues researched the causal mechanisms, diagnosis, etiology, and the treatment of Lyme disease, and the prevention of Lyme disease by a vaccine. All Malawista's sabbaticals were spent in Paris collaborating with various French colleagues. Malawista received several major awards, among them the Gold Medal of the American College of Rheumatology, the Ciba-Geigy/International League Against Rheumatism Prize with Allen Steere, and the degree of Docteur Honoris Causa from the Universite de Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers include correspondence with individuals and organizations; administrative reports of the Section of Rheumatology; Yale committee minutes and correspondence; grants and contracts whether funded or not; manuscripts of papers, both published and unpublished, including correspondence with editors, reviews, and subsequent resubmissions to the same or other journals; popular and scholarly materials collected by Malawista on Lyme disease; presentations and travels to conferences; articles/reprints; protocols; and laboratory notebooks. Restricted materials containing patient information include Malawista's correspondence with patients, clinical research, clinical trials, and most research notebooks.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Most of the papers are open for research, but portions of the collection are restricted because they contain patient data. Consult the Librarian for Medical History.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 12 series: 1. General. 2. Correspondence. 3. Yale University: Administration, Teaching, Medical Practice, Sabbaticals. 4. Submission of manuscripts for publication. 5. Grant and contract proposals. 6. Lyme disease files, Part 1 (open). 7. Lyme disease files, Part 2 (restricted). 8. Lyme Vaccine Study (restricted). 9. Talks and Travel ("T/T"). 10. Published articles (reprints). 11. Research materials. 12. Oversize.

did.unittitle: Application for the International Geigy Rheumatism Prize

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stephen E. Malawista, Allen C. Steere, and John A. Hardin applied as a group for the prize in 1980 based on their research on Lyme disease. The prize was awarded by the International League Against Rheumatism (ILAR). Malawista received a rejection letter for the application in 1981.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Allen C. Steere and Stephen E. Malawista were jointly awarded this prize in 1986. Folder contains a brief note from the New Haven Register and large format photographs taken at the award ceremony.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This event commemorating the work of Malawista took place on April 22-23, 2004. There was a dinner in the evening, and a symposium the next day, followed by a tour of the art museum. The folder contains the program for "Neutrophils and Inflammation: A symposium in Honor of Stephen E. Malawista, MD" held at Yale on April 23, 2004, and lists of the numerous people invited to attend the various events. There is a poster for the symposium in Box 82.

did.unittitle: Yale Patent Policy - Invention disclosure concerning cryopreservable cytoplasts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Malawista proposed to patent "Two types of cryopreservable cytoplasts from human polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN) that maintain motile, phagocytic, and microbial function." He submitted an Invention Disclosure form to Yale but was informed by Robert Bickerton of the Office of Cooperative Research that the invention was not patentable "in its present stage of development."

did.unittitle: Yale University Office of Cooperative Research concerning rights in Malawista's inventions, OCR142 and OCR791

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Malawista's further attempt to patent his invention (OCR 142) was declined by the Yale OCR and, at Malawista's request, the invention was released to him to patent and commercialize as he pleased, on condition that Yale received a portion of net income. The correspondence also concerns a second invention, "Antibody for the Detection of Gamma Related Proteins" (OCR791). Yale offered to release this invention to Malawista also.

did.unittitle: Section of Rheumatology, Department of Internal Medicine
Annual Reports of the Section of Rheumatology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are annual reports of the Section of Rheumatology to the Department of Internal Medicine. For most of these reports, Malawista was serving as chief of the section. Early reports contain names of faculty, clinical staff, postdoctoral fellows, promotions, forthcoming appointments, terminations, current educational program, research in progress, and publications. Later reports became increasingly more elaborate and included clinical activity, program grants, educational activities, community activities, goals, and individual reports of each faculty member. The section grew under Malawista's leadership.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Malawista spent every sabbatical he was granted as well as triennial leaves in Paris collaborating with various French colleagues, especially Anne Chevance. These folders contain arrangements for his leaves from Yale and sometimes correspondence with Yale laboratory colleagues during his leave. Research notes from some of his sabbaticals can be found in Series 11.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Malawista spent his first sabbatical in 1971-1972 at the Centre de Genetique Moleculaire under Boris Ephrussi. This folder contains only a postcard from Paris announcing his return to New Haven (stamp removed prior to donation). More information might be found in Series 2, Correspondence, under Boris Ephrussi.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sabbatical, the best documented, was spent at the Institut de Pathologie Cellulaire, Kremlin-Bicetre, under Marcel Bessis. The folder contains correspondence arranging for the sabbatical including Malawista's letter to Bessis asking to work in his laboratory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains primarily correspondence with the Rheumatology Section, especially with Wanda Prinz, section secretary, when Malawista was away in Paris. He sent her tapes to transcribe, and listed matters to take care of, and she forwarded correspondence sent to the Section. Various Yale matters were discussed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files correspond with numbered entries in Malawista's Curriculum Vitae. See Box 1 for his CVs. His 2012 CV is also attached to this finding aid. Full citations have been copied and slightly rearranged from Malawista's CV. Early citations may not include end pages because Malawista and PubMed did not include them.

Files may include correspondence with journal editors and coauthors, peer reviews of his submissions, Malawista's responses to reviews, comments of Yale faculty, drafts, notes, photographs, and diagrams. In many cases the initial submission was rejected or required revision. Often rejected manuscripts would be sent to one or more other journals. See also Subseries 3, "Manuscripts not published or not included in list of publications."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Malawista, S.E. and Bodel, Phyllis T. "The dissociation by colchicine of phagocytosis from increased oxygen consumption in human leukocytes," rejected by the Journal of Experimental Medicine . The manuscript was then sent to the British Journal of Experimental Pathology which also rejected it.
Folder contains correspondence, 1965-1966, and a copy of the paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Malawista, S.E. and Bodel, Phyllis .T. "The dissociation by colchicine of phagocytosis from increased oxygen consumption in human leukocytes," J. Clin. Invest. 46[5]: 786-796, May l967.

After the previous rejection (Articles 12a), the paper was then submitted to the Journal of Clinical Investigation on April 18, 1966. It was rejected in its current form on June 17, 1966 and resubmitted. A paper on the subject was presented by Malawista and Bodel at The Society for Clinical Investigation, Atlantic City, New Jersey, May 2, 1966.

Folder contains correspondence, 1966-1967, reviews, drafts, photographs, notes, the program of the meeting, drafts of the paper, a request from JAMA to abstract it, and a copy of the published abstract ( JAMA 200[9], May 29, 1967: 166).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Malawista, S.E. and Bensch, Klaus G. "Human polymorphonuclear leukocytes: Demonstration of microtubules and effect of colchicine," Science l56:52l, l967.
This article was initially sent to Nature but rejected by the editor. It was resubmitted to Science , sent to reviewers and published. Correspondence, 1966-1967, drafts, photograph.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alan Steere, S.E. Malawista, David R. Snydman, Robert E. Shope, Warren A. Andiman, Martin R. Ross, and Frances M. Steele, "Lyme Arthritis: An epidemic of oligoarticular arthritis in children and adults in three Connecticut communities," submitted to NEJM and rejected.

This was to be the first published research paper on Lyme disease. The paper was rejected in part for internal reasons, but also because the observations had been publicized elsewhere. The editor wrote, "Under such conditions the Journal is apt to consider the material as already published."

Correspondence with Franz J. Ingelfinger, editor of NEJM , June-August 1976, reviews, drafts of response, drafts of paper, Yale announcement to press, December 12, 1976, earlier talk on "Lyme arthritis," and copy of announcement of "Lyme arthritis," in the Medical Tribune , July 21, 1976.

odd.head: General
odd.p: This is a category in Malawista's CV for published articles that are not original research, but rather summarize what is known on a topic. Under reviews are the many chapters Malawista wrote for textbooks. Folders are keyed to the numbering in Malawista's 2012 CV. See Box 1, Folder 1, or version of CV attached to this collection.

did.unittitle: S.E. Malawista and A.C. Steere, paper on three cases of erythema chronica migrans

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The paper on three cases of the condition in Americans who had visited Europe was rejected by Annals of Internal Medicine , but Steere and Malawista were asked instead to work with a dermatologist "to prepare an editorial note that would call attention to the emergence of erythema chronicum migrrans as a 'new' problem." The association of the skin lesion with Lyme arthritis would be part of the editorial note. Folder contains just the rejection letter from Edward Huth, M.D., editor of the journal.

did.unittitle: Major NIH grants: NIH R01 AR10493: "Biophysical Mechanisms in Leukocytes and Melanocytes"

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: "Biophysical Mechanisms in Leukocytes and Melanocytes," was Stephen Malawista's main grant from the National Institutes of Health. It lasted under the same title for over 35 years until Malawista closed it out in 2008.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries is missing the original grant proposal but does include non-competitive continuations, renewals, requests for changes, correspondence with NIH officials, and related materials from 1975 to 2008. The number following R01 AR10493 corresponds to the number of years the grant was held.

Major NIH grants: NIH R21 AR003457: "Resolution of Gouty Inflammation"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The R21 type grant was an "Exploratory/Developmental Research Grant." Malawista was the P.I., Ruth Montgomery also worked on the grant, and Charles Serhan of Harvard was a consultant.

did.unittitle: Major NIH grants: NIH Program Project Grant: 1 P01 AI39548, "Lyme Disease: Pathogenesis and Protection," Stephen W. Barthold, P.I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This was a 5-year Program Project Grant on Lyme disease in which many Yale physicians and scientists collaborated. Stephen Barthold, DVM, PhD, was in the Section of Comparative Medicine at Yale. Malawista was P.I. of the second project of the grant, "Host-Parasite Interactions that Determine the Rate of B. burgdorferi in vivo." The grant was awarded in 1991.

did.unittitle: NIH Program Project Grant, "Lyme Disease; Pathogenesis and Protection," Fred Kantor, P. I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Initial application for this large grant with several parts, each with its own principal investigator. Malawista was to be in charge of Project #2, "Probes for B. burgorferi DNA in Ticks, Mice and Men." This version of the proposal was presumably not approved. The 1991 proposal with Stephen Barthold as P.I. did receive funding for five years.

did.unittitle: NIH 1 P01 AI30548, "Lyme Disease; Pathogenesis and Protection," Stephen Barthold, P.I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a much expanded renewal application consisting of "five interactive projects and three supporting cores." The request was for over 7 million dollars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Another attempt at renewal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The NIH-sponsored training program in investigative rheumatology was begun in 1976. It trained both M.D.s and Ph.D.s in an area "that focuses upon the mechanisms of rheumatologic and immunologic diseases." Malawista was one of 21 collaborators.

NIH: N01-AI-50031, "Toll-Like Receptor Responsiveness in the Elderly and Immunosuppressed, Erol Fikrig, P.I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This was to be a large multi-investigator project involving Malawista and Ruth Montgomery, among others. The proposal was "in response to the announcement of a contract to address immune function and biodefense in immunocompromised patients groups." This proposal was called by Malawista the "Biodefense Contract." It would especially concern West Nile Virus.
The folder contains materials on planning for the application, including IRB approval, but not the proposal itself.

did.unittitle: NIH: Pilot Feasibility Study as part of the Yale Skin Disease Research Core Center

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Yale Disease Research Core Center, sponsored by NIH, was under Dr. Robert E. Tigelaar, Professor of Dermatology and Immunobiology at Yale. Malawista's proposal, "Modulation of the Inflammatory Response in Human Plasma," was sent to NIH in both 2005 and 2006 and was a small grant for $25,000 in direct costs to work with Tigelaar. It may not have been funded.

scopecontent.p: The original proposal asked for $69,593 for two years, 1969 to 1971. Among those supported in part by this proposal were Drs. Robert Gifford and James D. Kenney. The Arthritis Foundation approved $12,000 for one year. Malawista noted that he had previously received grants from the Arthritis Foundation and its Connecticut Chapter.

did.unittitle: Contracts with drug and other companies
Hematek Partners, Scheer & Company, Branford, Conn., "Chemotactic, phagocytic, and microbial function of stored human polymorphonuclear leukocytes"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a "Business Plan" by Hematek to "develop a novel, proprietary technology that makes possible the extended storage of granulocytes." Included in the folder is Malawista's description of the six-month project.

did.unittitle: Pfizer, Groton, Conn., P.I. Paul Hoffer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Paul Hoffer, professor of diagnostic radiology at Yale, proposed to investigate of "A radionuclide method to monitor the progress of rheumatoid arthritis." The primary object was to validate the use of Ga-67 to "assess the efficacy of drug treatment." Malawista was an advisor on this project.

did.unittitle: G.D. Searle & Co., Chicago: "Effect of Colchicine on Rheumatoid Arthritis Disease Activity in Patients Concurrently Taking Misoprostol and NSAIDS"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Although called a grant, this funding provided to Malawista was more like a contract from the drug company G.D. Searle to do a clinical test of its drug Cytotec (misoprostol). Misoprostal was similar to the natural prostaglandins, and could serve as a replacement for patients taking aspirin and similar drugs (NSAIDs) that could cause ulcers.

did.unittitle: G.D. Searle: published materials on Cytotec (misoprostol)
Therakos, West Chester, Pa.: "Extracorporeal Treatment of Rheumatoid Arthritis" (Restricted)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The project was to test the therapeutic effect of photopheresis on rheumatoid arthritis. Folder includes correspondence, a protocol (4978), and patient names. Restricted.

did.unittitle: Therakos: Malawista, letter to U.S. Rep. John D. Dingell

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of complaint for how his project was treated at the meeting of the FDA Rheumatoid Arthritis Advisory Panel. Dingell was Chairman of the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Malawista maintained a category for material on Lyme disease, but the materials were disorganized. Materials on Lyme disease were scattered throughout his papers. This series contains papers that do not have individual patient information and therefore are open for research. The clippings, popular articles, and research articles were all collected by Malawista. The arrangement of this series is that of the archivist. Malawista's papers on Lyme disease can be found under Series 4, Submission of manuscripts for publication, and Series 10, Published articles(reprints). His presentations on Lyme disease and Yale symposia on Lyme disease are under Series 9, Talks and Travel.

Malawista correspondence on the Lyme Borreliosis Foundation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Lyme Borreliosis Foundation, Tolland, Connecticut, headed by Karen Vanderhoof-Forschner, was a patient advocacy group, which often differed from Lyme researchers such as Malawista. The particular subject here was a paper given by Eliot Frank, M.D., at the Fourth Annual Conference of Lyme Borreliosis, to which Vanderhoof-Forschner strongly objected and sent a letter to Frank's superior at the Jersey Shore Medical Center. Malawista wrote on behalf of Frank.

did.unittitle: Research with Soren Nielsen and James B. Peters, Specialty Laboratories, Inc., on a test for Lyme disease

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Malawista was collaborating with Nielsen and Peters, Specialty Laboratories, Inc., Santa Monica, California, sending samples (CSF) from Lyme patients to test the ability of "PCR to permit the specific identification of B. burgdorferi DNA in fluids and tissues." Joint efforts led to an abstract: Soren L. Niesen, James B. Peter, Robert T. Schoen, Daniel W. Rahn, and Stephen E. Malawista, "B. burgdorferi Persistently Detected by PCR in Synovial Fluid of a Patient with Lyme Disease Resistant to Therapy," December 1989. Soren and Peter did not collaborate on any paper in Malawista's CV. File contains patient information.

scopecontent.p: This series was maintained by Malawista's successive secretaries who created files for talks away from Yale and for professional meetings. Sometimes folders were created for events Malawista probably didn't attend. Additional material on talks and meetings was found loose in Malawista's papers and added by the archivist to "T/T." Folders may contain correspondence, programs, announcements, abstracts of papers that Malawista and his colleagues presented, texts of talks, and occasional photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

McCarty, ARA meeting, Chicago, June 21, 1962; and a copy of the abstract of the paper discussed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: When he published an article, Malawista purchased as many as 400 printed copies (reprints) of it. Reprints could often be ordered with covers or without. Malawista ordered some of each. He sent reprints in response to postcard requests, included selected reprints in grants, and brought relevant reprints to talks and meetings to give to those who were interested. Later in his career, when journals began to be published online, printed reprints were no longer as available. By 2010 the culture of trading reprints had largely ended. Reprints were found scattered in Malawista's collection. They are here organized by year and include both peer-reviewed articles and "reviews" (see CV in Box 1, Folder 1, and attached to finding aid). Reprints that Malawista received from others have not been kept except for those on Lyme disease.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These protocols for research were identified by number and approved annually by the Yale University Human Investigation Committee. Protocols typically do not contain patient names, although the Lyme disease protocols in Series 8, Lyme Vaccine Study, do have reports on adverse reactions identified by study participant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The trial was to test anti-metabolite therapy in patients with SLE nephritis. The drug to be tested as an immunosuppressive was Azathioprine ("Imuran").

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are notebooks kept in Malawista's laboratory. Most of the notebooks, except for those titled "Frog Skins," contain tests on fluids or tissues of named patients or donors. Malawista's staff often volunteered blood or other fluids for testing. The bulk of laboratory notes were entered in blank books, often purchased from the Yale Co-Operative Corporation. Other laboratory notes, overlapping in time, were maintained in three-ring binders.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Hidemi Sato was at the Marine Biological Laboratory, Woods Hole, with Malawista. At this time Sato was in the Department of Biology, University of Pennsylvania. Malawista and Sato collaborated on several papers.
